sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Very extraordinary news, indeed.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: He for ever quits claim to Lucinda.—A'n't I a lucky fellow?—Hortensia has fix'd the affair at last.—Ha! ha!—My dear Wisely, you don't enjoy my happiness.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: To see one's friends happy, Sir, is—

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Was not I right not to fume and fret?—Ha! ha!—I kept my temper, you see.—Ha! ha!—Is not it the luckiest thing in the world?

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: [With a forc'd laugh.] Such luck never was heard of.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Wisely—Bellfield—how do ye, lads?—Wisely, give me joy:—I have had a most admirable escape from the galling yoke of matrimony.—I have done with the widow, my boy.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: [In spirits.] Have you?

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: [Uneasy.] Done with her!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Yes, completely:—She's a compound of deceit, affectation, treachery, and fraud.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: My dear Careless, she's a very fine woman.—Marry her stiil, man.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: You have hit her character, Careless. I should be sorry any friend of mine—

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Ay; I know her thoroughly.—I shall mortify her pride:—I'll gall her proud heart:—You'll see me to-morrow married to Lucinda.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: And the widow will be so provok'd—

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Zoons! Sir, but let me tell you—

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—You wanted me to make her amends a little while ago: I could not then; but now I'm at liberty, I shall certainly do it.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Sure the widow is a much finer woman.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Oh! no, no, no [laughing].

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Not to be compar'd to her, Careless.—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I shall certainly marry her, Bellfield.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: But, Sir, do you imagine— [angrily.]

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: She's beautiful as an angel:—Young, accomplish'd, elegant—

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Mr. Careless, what do you mean by this?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Why, won't you let me praise her?—Wisely, he was going to cut my throat a while ago, for abusing her; and now he wants to murder me for speaking in her commendation—But make yourself easy, my dear Bellfield, I shall marry her.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Marry her! Damnation!

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: No violence, Bellfield: Careless is very right [holds Bellfield.] She's a sweet girl, Careless.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Yes; I know she is.—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Marry her by all means.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Most certainly.—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Let go your hold, Mr. Wisely.—I desire, Sir—

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Lads, for shame!—not ready for the ball!—Hey! what! quarrelling!—never quarrel, my dear Bellfield—never be out of humour.—Passion unhinges the whole frame; [turning out his toes] destroys the grace and gaiety, and—

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: My dear knight, you're always in good humour; give us your hand.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Always, Sir; always in spirits.—Bellfield, I have made a new country-dance since I saw you.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: I heard some bad news; and so I did it to shake off melancholy.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Bad news!—What's the matter, Sir Philip?

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p:
Poor lady Portsoken!—You know I told you I used to dance with her.—I received a letter, mentioning, that after a venison feast at her house last week, as she was amusing herself over a quart of syllabub, she was taken suddenly ill, and expired [sinks and rises]. I was very much
shocked; so I composed a dance to raise my spirits.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Hang him, a troublesome fellow.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: I am very sorry for her, I assure you.—Bellfield, it's a charming dance; all briskness and activity.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Po! po!

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Foot it at top, cast off two couple, foot if at bottom, dance corners—

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: I shall be glad to speak a word with you in private.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Dance corners, I say, out at sides, cross over, turn your partner, right hand and left.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Shall us dance it this evening, Sir Philip?

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, this evening.—But come, the hour draws nigh.—For shame, lads!—Wisely, Bellfield, ye both live near my house;—come, and make ye ready.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: I can't go directly now.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: You must; I have business with you.— [Aside to Bellfield.] Lucinda shall be your own still.—I have business with you too, Sir Philip.—Come, Bellfield, I insist upon it. Forcing him off.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I attend you.—Careless, foot it at top, cast off two couple. Dances out.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: An ungenerous woman to treat me thus!—I'll master up resolution to despise her, and never converse with her again.
sp.stage: Enter HORTENSIA, and passes by him.
sp.p: So, so, dissembling woman! [looking after her.]

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Low, vile wretch!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I'll not expostulate the matter with her.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: I'll not condescend to upbraid him.— [Goes up to him.] Mr. Careless, you're a villain.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: [Pretends to laugh.] Oh, Ma'am, I am fully acquainted with your sentiments already.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: A cool, deliberate villain!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Unfeeling in all points of honour as in love.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Pleasant, upon my soul!—She upbraids me too!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: That unmanly sneer!—Mr. Careless, Mr. Careless, after every proof of love a weak, inconsiderare woman could give—I will only now take the liberty to tell you, the baseness of your heart will make you the aversion of our sex, and the scorn of your own.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Since I must speak, Heaven is my witness, I never fail'd in caution and respect for you; I never abused the confidence you reposed in me; nobody breathing ever heard a syllable of our loves.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: No, Sir?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: No; not a mortal.—You made me break off with Lucinda, and now—

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Could you favour me with a pinch of snuff?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I have not my box about me.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Shall I presume to offer you a pinch of mine?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: She's coming to again, by all that's tender!—Ha! ha!—I see how it is. [Aside.]— [Turns to her.] You are very obliging.—How!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Do you own your baseness now?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: How came that in your hands?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: You could send it back with an affronting message too.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I, Ma'am!—By heaven, nobody ever handled it, or knew your picture was there, except my friend Wisely.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Wisely.—Excepting him, nobody ever—

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Oh, blockhead! fool! [Walks about.] You told him then?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Yes, yes—I told him—I told him all—I desired him to take it to town, and get it mended—I let him into the whole secret—I knew I could trust him.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: The man on earth you should not have trusted: He was your rival; and he contriv'd this mischief. He sent it back to me, as from you.—That's the use he has made of your confidence in him.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Oh! I see my folly.—Damnation!—And so the letter I receiv'd—

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Sir, I repent me of that letter.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: [Looking pleased.] Do you?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Most heartily.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Blessings on you for the word.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: [Angry.] What, you are glad, are you?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: To rapture.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: [With a sneer.] I promise you, you shall never receive such another.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Then I return it to you most joyfully.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Very well, Sir! you return a fond letter thus with scorn.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Fond do you call it?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Was it no fondness to tell you here— [opens the letter.] What's this? oh, I see through this too! Now blush for your indiscretion, weak, trifling man! This very letter I sent Mr. Wisely, when first my foolish heart seduc'd me to listen to your addresses.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Shame and confusion! ideot that I was!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: How paltry do you appear now.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I feel it all.—And yet will you suffer him, Wisely, to succeed in so ungenerous a plot?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: He has acted like a man of sense: he has at once shewn me his own prudence, and the infirmity of your frivolous mind.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: But in all my conduct you see no marks of guilt, no treachery, no—

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Sir, it is to me the same thing if an idle imbecility of understanding assumes the appearance, or acts the purposes, of every vice in its turn.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: And can you thus, for a small failure—

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Small failure do you call it? Mr. Wisely has deserv'd me, and I'll bestow myself upon him this very day, to shew the value I have for the man who has honour enough to keep a woman's secrets, and the contempt due to the wretch who, like you, can trifle with a generous heart.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Hell and the devil! I shall never be able to shew my face after this:—Blunt will rail at me, my enemies will rejoice, and every female tongue will clack, clack.—Confusion!—What's to be done?—I'll follow her to Sir Philip's mask; and from this moment not one unguarded word shall ever escape me. Exit.

div3.head: SCENE a Room in Sir Philip's House.
div3.stage: Enter Sir PHILIP, WISELY, and BELLFIELD.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: You amaze me, Mr. Wisely.—Careless a design upon my wife!

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: He has laid his plot as I have told you.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Why this is enough to spoil a man's dancing indeed. [Dances.]

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Be directed by me, and you shall at once have full proof, and be able to prevent the mischief.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: [Dancing.] I was never so disconcerted in my born days.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Your own eyes, your own ears, shall convince you.—Wisely, [aside to Wisely] I'll step and see if Lucinda's ready.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: [Aside to Bellfield.] Does she enter with spirit into the scheme?

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Most chearfully.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Well, step and speak to her once more. [Exit Bellfield.] This will finish him with Hortensia. [Aside.]—The levity of this man, Sir Philip, his own folly, has put it in my power to do you this service.—Hush! I see Careless coming; I know his dress.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: And there's comes my wife; I know her dress too.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Sir Philip, get you behind that curtain:—quick—quick;—your happiness depends upon it.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: I am gone. [Goes behind the curtain hanging to the back scene.]

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Now, now, this is the very crisis of his fate.

div3.stage: Enter CARELESS and LUCINDA, at opposite doors, both masked.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Her ladyship is true to her appointment, I see. [Unmasks.]—My lady Figurein, this is generous indeed.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: The ball-room's full. [In a feign'd voice.]

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: And we are safe here.—Come, come, let me hear the gentle accents of your own sweet voice.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: No; I love to practise.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: [Peeping behind.] I never knew such perfidy in my life.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Now then the opportunity favours—let us retire to compleat each others' bliss.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: You shall dance [sinks and rises] to another tune presently.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: I've something to say to you first:—I hear you're going to marry that flirt, Lucinda.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Lucinda!—Ha! ha!—That will never be!—Marry her!—A proud insolent, who over-rates both her beauty and her fortune.—I never had a sincere regard for her; I gave the girl hopes, and pamper'd her vain imagination, but I never liked her.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that;—I am afraid her character is not the best.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: If it has a flaw, she uses it like broken china; patches it up as well as she can, and turns the fairest side to view.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: But then you'll marry Hortensia.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: That will be as things happen.—But as to her, she'll be of no inconvenience to our amours; I shall always be able to detach a part of my time from her, in order to dedicate it more happily to love and joy with your ladyship.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Such a villain never entered a gentleman's house!

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: I am very faint of a sudden.—Throw up that window yonder.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Don't alarm yourself. [Drawing up the curtain, and looking towards her.] Your ladyship will be well in a moment.—Sir Philip will never suspect, or be able to find us out. He'll be busy with the graces.— [Making fast the string of the curtain, sees him.] Damnation! [Walks away.]

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: [Following him.] Mr. Careless, this is the vilest proceeding—the basest usage, Sir—the wickedest dssign—it's enough to put a body in a passion.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Zoons! what shall I do now?

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: I did not think you capable of this—nor your ladyship either:—Come, shew your face, madam, and let me see how guilt becomes it.— [Takes off her mask.] Lucinda all this time!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: How!—This is worse and worse.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Philip, the gay, the giddy Lucinda.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: And my wife innocent all the time!

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: Entirely:—We concerted this scheme amongst ourselves to detect that gentleman.—Mr. Careless, you never had a sincere regard for me, I think; and I have a flaw in my character, have not I?—Ha! ha!—Poor, detected Mr. Careless.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I deserve it all—I brought it all on myself.
Your humble servant, Mr. Careless.—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: A swarm of enemies all at work against me.—This is your damn'd designing head, Wisely.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Mr. Careless, [in a minuet step] this is the grossest violation of all friendship, honour, and hospitality—and, Sir, I shall hope to see you no more in my house.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I shall take another opportunity to explain this matter, Sir Philip; and for the present I— [going].
She too here!—Oh, I'm in high luck!

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: Hortensia, here has been such a discovery!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: I have heard it all, my dear—I have been attending in the next room.—Mr. Careless, what must I think of you now?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Every thing that's harsh, I make no doubt.—Blunt, you see what a condition I'm in here.

sp.speaker: BLUNT.
sp.p: I knew you'd be a bankrupt in fame as well as love at last.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! I can't stand it—it's too much to bear.—I here take my leave of ye all. [Going]

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: No, Sir, your presence is necessary:—You shall be a witness to an act of justice.—Mr. Wisely, I now acknowledge before this company, that I have behaved indelicately to you:—But now Sir, without ceremony, I give you my hand; at once to make atonement for my past conduct, and to shew that wretch the just reward of secrecy in love.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Generous Hortensia!

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: And, to do full and ample justice on him, Mr. Bellfield, I have been a very tyrant to you. I have used you like—What was your simile, Mr. Careless?—My airs were too thin for a lover to subsist upon; and so now I'll let in a little common-sense to keep him alive—Here, take me, Mr. Bellfield, that the gentleman may also see the just reward of sincerity in love.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Then I am paid indeed.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Poor Careless! I almost pity him.—He has had his dance, and now he pays the piper.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Oh, mighty well!—you may laugh.—I shall leave ye in possession of your mirth. [Throwing off his mask.] Ha! ha!—I fancy, though, you'll see that I can meet with a success elsewhere equal to any of ye.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Ay, ay, go on—enjoy the joke:——I shan't drop the least hint of my future schemes; but I believe—

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Poor Careless!—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: In a little time you'll know it all.—I shall depart for the county of Norfolk; and you may possibly read, in a few days, in the Norwich Journal, of Miss Belvidere and your humble servant—That's all.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: O brave! a sieve to the very last.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: I have known them dance fifty couple at the Norwich assembly.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Well, well; I'll say no more. [Going.]

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: [Stopping him.] Mr. Careless, since no injury is done me, I am willing to hope this day's business will correct your future conduct.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: You are very good, Sir Philip.—It will be a lesson to me for the rest of my life.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Then let us dance away reflection for the precent.—I won't be disappointed:—You shall sacrifice to the graces with me.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: With all my heart:—I have no ill will to any one.—Wisely, I deserve it, for putting myself in your power.—Blunt, spare my confusion.—I have been a very silly fellow:—But since things are come to this issue, I have the consolation to feel, that whatever may have been my indiscretions, I am greatly above a selfish and ungenerous character: I scorn a base action as much as any man in England.
sp.l: The careless indiscreet (this day has shewn)
Is no One's Enemy except His Own.
